I have the bird and cage, cap, and boots; the inspector was booking the charge, and asked the prisoner what he had done with it - he said he had had the sovereign, and bought a pair of new boots, a cap, and some fire-works; he gave his mother 1s. 6d., and his father 4s; I was sent to the house, and found his father and mother both intoxicated; I brought the bird and cage, fire-works, and cap down to the office - his father and mother were discharged.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Transported for Seven Years .

241.
CHARLES CLARK
and
ANN CLARK
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of November , 1 featherbed, value 15s.; 1 bolster, value 5s.; 2 pillows, value 2s.; 2 blankets, value 5s.; 1 quilt, value 2s., and 3 pictures, value 2s. , the goods of
William Bird
.

MARGARET BIRD
. I am the wife of William Bird - we live in Regent-place
. The prisoners lodged in my house for six weeks; they had only one room - they livedtogether as man and wife; they told the Magistrate they were not married - the woman was generally locked in her room, and very seldom had her door open; she was beating her child - I went up to see what she was beating it for, and missed the property.

WILLIAM HENRY LLOYD
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a quilt, which was pawned for 1s., by an elderly female. not the prisoner.

HENRY GILBERT
WELLS (Police-constable B 138.) I apprehended the two prisoners - the woman gave me these duplicates out of a little bag; they led me to the pawnbroker's - the man was not there, but came home afterwards.

JAMES PANTON
. I am a pawnbroker. I have three pillows, one bolster, and one blanket, which were pawned most of them, to the best of my rcollection, by the female prisoner; none of them by the man.

JOHN REYNOLDS
. I have a blanket, pawned by the female prisoner.

HORACE PECKOVER
. I have two pictures, pawned by the female prisoner.

MARGARET BIRD
. These are my property.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe the man was in the habit of going out early in the morning to work, and coming home late at night? A. Yes, he was.

Ann Clark
. It is perfectly clear it was my own doing.

A. CLARK -
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .

C. CLARK -
NOT GUILTY .

242.
WILLIAM HILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of November , 13 padlocks, value 3s.; 2 bedwinches, value 1s.; 3 pairs of snuffers, value 1s.; 5 corkscrews, value 1s. 6d., and 2 snuffer-trays, value 4d. , the goods of
James Connolly
.

JAMES CONNOLLY. On Thursday, the 8th of November, I went into the George and Crown public-house, Broad-street
, with these goods, consisting of some locks and other articles - I put them down by my left-hand side, and turned round to show the goods I had to sell to some other persons, and this pocket was gone; I do not know who took it till the Saturday following.

JOHN STORR
(Police-constable F 78). I stopped the prisoner with this pack on the Thursday night - I asked what he had got; he said he did not know, but a cab-man gave it to him to carry; there were thirteen padlocks, some cork-screws, and other things - a key was found in his pocket, which fitted one of the locks.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found them.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Seven Years .

243.
WILLIAM JOHNSON
and
WILLIAM CROSS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of November , 45 yards of flannel, value 2l. , the goods of
James Chapple
.

WILLIAM BRISTY
. I live with Mr. James Chapple, of High-street, Pentonville
. On the 24th of November I was behind the counter - Johnson came to the door, took up the flannel, and ran away with it: I ran out, and saw him carrying the flannel, with Cross behind him, not one door off - they were taken about two doors off the house; this is the flannel - I marked it on Friday night, and it was taken on Saturday night.

JAMES FOX
(Police-constable N 196). I was on duty near this shop on Saturday night, the 24th of November - I saw the prisoner go to the door together, and which took the flannel I could not tell, but Johnson had it when I took them into custody.
JOHNSON - GUILTY. Aged 24.
CROSS - GUILTY. Aged 21.

Judgment Respited
.

244.
ANN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of November , 1 canvas bag, value 2d., and 8 sovereigns, the property of
William Incell
, from his person .

WILLIAM INCELL
. I am a corn-chandler , and live on Stepney-green. On the 26th of November, at twenty minutes after nine o'clock in the evening, I met the prisoner in Whitechapel-road - she was a stranger; she asked where I was going - I said to Stepney; she said she lived there herself, and we walked on together - it was rather dark at the time; I had been taking a glass with a few friends - all on a sudden, when we got to Hanibal-street
, she said she saw somebody she knew; I felt my purse, which contained eight sovereigns, drawn from my trouser's pocket - we were stopping at the time, as she said she lived there; I called the Policeman, who came and took her - I had not given her the purse, nor taken any liberty with her.

GEORGE WALTER SHEW
(Police-constable K 50). I was called, and saw the prosecutor holding the prisoner - she wanted to get away; it was about half-past eight o'clock - he accused her of stealing his money, and she denied it; my brother-officer searched her - I heard a sovereign drop, and picked it up; I found the purse after she had gone to the station, about two yards from where I first saw her - it was empty; seven sovereigns were found tied in her shawl.

WILLIAM HOMER
(Police-constable K 173). I took off the prisoner's shawl at the station, to search her, but the inspector said he would send for a woman - the shawl was then on the table - the inspector took it up, and found seven sovereigns, tied up at the end of it; this is the money.
Prisoner's Defence. He accosted me first; the sovereigns are not his - he offered me 1s.; the purse fell down, and I took it up.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

245.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of November , 1 pair of trousers, value 4s. 6d. , the goods of
Samuel Dias
.

SAMUEL DIAS
. I live in Brick-lane
. These trousers were hanging on a pole, tied round with a rope - I did not see them taken, but my attention was drawn by my servant - the prisoner was brought back after I gave information.

FRANCES FLOOD
. I live with the prosecutor - I cannot swear to the prisoner, but I saw a hand go up, and the trousers pulled down - I gave information, and saw the prisoner brought back to the house afterwards.

LEWIS HARRIS
. The prosecutor on Wednesday, the 28th, called at my master's, and said he had lost a pair of trousers - the prisoner afterwards came and offered the trousers for sale, and I gave information.

THOMAS FENTON
. I was sent by Harris to the prosecutor, with the prisoner and the trousers.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. My brother came home and asked me to go to buy him a waistcoat - I was going down Petticoat-lane, and saw a man with these trousers; he asked 6s. for them, and taking some of my brother's money, I went to pawn them, to get the money back.

GUILTY .* Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

246.
GEORGE JORDAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of October , 4lbs. of lamb, value 3s. , the goods of
John Williams
.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I had this lamb in my hand at the corner of Milton-street
; I turned to speak to two girls, and the prisoner snatched it from me - I pursued him, but I fell down; he got off, and I did not see him again till he was in custody - I knew him very well.

PAUL PLANT
(Police-constable G 156). I took the prisoner for smashing, and as I thought he resembled the person who took the lamb, I took the prosecutor to him.

Prisoner's Defence. He was very much in liquor - two women had told of his arm; he asked me to have something to drink - we went into the Paul - I staid there some time, and then he said I had got his shoulder of mutton; I said I had not - he said, "Has Jenny got it;" I said, "I don't know;" we then came out - I was afterwards taken on another charge; I saw no mutton with him.
JOHN WILLIAMS. I had not drank with him, nor had any intimacy with him; I was sober - I changed a sovereign at the Paul, and lost 9s. 6d. there.
NOT GUILTY .

247.
CHARLOTTE VINCENT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of November , 1 shirt, value 4s. , the goods of
Robert Farrow
.

ELIZABETH FARROW
. I am a laundress, and am the wife of
Robert Farrow
- he lives in Luton-street
. This linen was brought into the house for me to wash, and in about three minutes it was gone; I went to the station-house, and then to some pawnbrokers, and found the shirt - I did not see the prisoner; my child described the prisoner to me - the things were taken from the parlour, the door of which was open.

HENRY SWAIN
. I am a pawnbroker - I live about a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's I have a shirt which was pawned by the prisoner, on the 24th of November, about nine o'clock at night - this is it.

WILLIAM JOHNS
(Police-constable D 41.) The prosecutrix came to me, said she had lost a shirt, and gave me a description of the girl and her dress - I went to Little Church-street, and found the prisoner at a temporary playhouse.
GUILTY. Aged 17.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

248.
SARAH ROBINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of November , 1 watch, value 50s., the goods of
Robert Lumley
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear NOT GUILTY .

249.
ROBERT HERN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of November , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Peter Dunne
, from his person .

PETER DUNNE. On the 27th of November, about ten o'clock in the morning, I was in Compton-street, Soho
- a witness said my pocket had been picked; I then felt, and missed my handkerchief, which was safe five or ten minutes before, when I left my employer's house; I have not found it.

GEORGE ISRAEL
. I am a jeweller. I saw the prisoner lift up the tail of the prosecutor's coat, and draw his handchief out; he was with three others - he was about to put it in his bosom; I lost sight of them for half a minute, then went and informed the prosecutor - we came up to the prisoner at the corner of Walker's-court; he made great resistance - I am sure he is the one who took it; he was the shortest of them.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you know him before? A. No.

THOMAS WILSON
. I am a constable. I saw the prisoner making a desperate resistance - I came up and took him.
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the handkerchief.
